results.title: The Poetry Cup
results.creator_credit: Terrence Doran, Ken Smeaton and Peter Lane
results.brief_description: The inaugural Poetry Cup was filmed in September at the Rochester Castle Hotel, Fitzroy as part of the 1989 Spoleto Fringe Festival. Just as the comedy resurgence began in the small cafes and clubs before moving to a wider television audience so then the poets. These people are performers with an emphasis on entertainment. No quiet reads here, but full blooded performance poetry. Their skills have been honed amid beer, smoke, pool players and football, in the back rooms of inner city hotels such as the Provincial, the Rochester, the Leicester Arms and cafes, prisons, schools and the streets.

results.title: Sorry book: Kutcha; Larry (A) [Reconciliation advertisements]
results.brief_description: These two short community advertisements (30 seconds each) were made to create awareness about the suffering of indigenous peoples as a result of forced removal from their families in the middle of twentieth century Australia. The audience is asked to consider the current impact experienced by these people today as a direct result of government policy whilst the Aboriginal people are still asking “why?”. Sign the “Sorry book” at www.apology.west.net.au.

results.title: The Platypus
results.creator_credit: Betti Wood, Concept Films of Australia and Pilgrim Films
results.brief_description: Animated Aboriginal dreamtime legend of the creation of the platypus with live action at the beginning and end of the film. Narrated by Ron Haddrick.

results.title: Banduk (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Di Drew, Penelope Spence and National Nine Network
results.brief_description: Banduk, a young Aboriginal girl, and her friends discover that the “friendly” proprietors of an ice-cream van are smuggling native animals, including the sacred red-collared parakeet, out of Australia. This delightful story was filmed on location in Arnhem Land.

results.title: The Landscape architects; Fire down below
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
“The Landscape architects” David Bellamy looks at how First Nations peoples learned to tame the countryside without becoming farmers, and at what sort of diet they enjoyed. “Fire Down Below” David Bellamy looks at the secrets of survival of the Australian flora against the frequent fires which seek to destroy.

results.title: Wharfies: A History of the Waterside Worker's Federation
results.brief_description: Wharfies traces the history of the Australian Waterside Workers Federation from its foundation in 1902, under Billy Hughes, to the present day. Made in the tradition of the Waterside Workers Film Unit of the 1950s, “Wharfies” covers important historical events including industrial milestones, political crises and the stories of the men themselves. This film is pieced together through dramatised sequences, interviews with veteran wharfies and rare archival footage. Cartoons, news clippings and old photographs all help to tell the story.

results.title: Australia's art of the Dreamtime: Quinkin country
results.creator_credit: Jim Needham and WIPB-TV, Ball State University
results.brief_description:
A documentary on the history of Australian First Nations peoples and their rock art in the Cape York Peninsula region of Queensland. The program explores not only the historical background of the rock paintings but theorises on the first arrival of First Nations peoples to this land and the formation of the landscape itself through archaeological, geological and palaeontological evidence.
During the 1950s Australian artist and author Percy Trezise went on a quest to locate the rock art around Laura in the Cape York region and through contact with First Nations elders and befriending First Nations writer, Dick Roughsey, he was eventually accepted as a “tribal brother”. In this program, Percy, using images from his own paintings, interprets First Nations Dreamtime stories, mythology and initiation ceremonies as represented by the rock paintings. He speaks of his own experiences and respect for First Nations peoples, their culture and their heritage. Voice over narration by Chris Schenkel. Note: Visual quality average - filmed on video camera. Arts 2002 and SBS Independent.

results.title: Shimmer in the city
results.creator_credit: Amanda Hickey and Special Broadcasting Service Corporation
results.brief_description: A detailed look at urban Aboriginal art through interviews with artists, national and international curators, art dealers and art critics, and their views on the place of the work in relation to traditional Aboriginal art as well as Australian society at large. The notion of preconceived ideas of Aboriginal art is discussed as well as the non-stereotypical aboriginality represented in the urban artist’s work where mythical, cultural and environmental heritage is referred to, but situated politically as a confrontation of past and present issues effecting indigenous Australians. Through the interviews with the artists and critics of their work the autobiographical nature of the art is evoked, underlining both the personal and broad social relevance of the art to contemporary Aboriginal experience. It is thorough documentary on the broad spectrum of work being produced that also raises the key issues of Aboriginal ownership of imagery and the question of Aboriginal copyright.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 01
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie is there for the announcement of the winner to the second Helen Lempriere National Sculpture Award at Werribee Park. Andrew speaks with contestants and judges including Inge King. At Gammaspace, an art auction to raise funds for the Easter protests at Woomera is covered and at the Centre for Contemporary Photography (CCP) the witty and playful collaborators Nat and Ali present their work the ‘Art Bar’. A performance/installation piece that explores celebrity, art politics, art and the alcoholic muse.
